name._: J. Alan Groves Center for Advanced Biblical Research

note: from the electronic version of the Leningrad Codex maintained by the J. Alan Groves Center for Advanced Biblical Research.

This text began as an electronic transcription by Richard Whitaker (Princeton Seminary, New Jersey) and H. van Parunak (then at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor) of the 1983 printed edition of Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia (BHS). It was continued with the cooperation of Robert Kraft (University of Pennsylvania) and Emmanuel Tov (Hebrew University, Jerusalem), and completed by Alan Groves (Westminster Theological Seminary).  The transcription was called the Michigan-Claremont-Westminster electronic Hebrew Bible and was archived at the Oxford Text Archive (OTA) in 1987. It has been variously known as the "CCAT" or "eBHS" text. Since that time, the text has been modified in many hundreds of places to conform to the photo-facsimile of the Leningrad Codex, Firkovich B19A, residing at the Russian National Library, St. Petersberg; hence the change of name.

The J. Alan Groves Center for Advanced Biblical Research has continued to scrutinize and correct this electronic text as a part of its continuing work of building morphology and syntax databases of the Hebrew Bible, since correct linguistic analysis requires an accurate text.
Vocalized ketib variants are no longer included as they are not part of the original manuscript.

The only changes to the J. Alan Groves Center for Advanced Biblical Research text by the transcriber are: The book names in English and Hebrew of the Jewish Publication Society Tanach and book abbreviations from the New Revised Standard Version have been added. Six transcription notes (5,7,10) have been moved to the noted character (Lev 11:42.4, Judg 18:30.11, Isa 9.6.1, Ps 80:14.3, Job 38:13.5, Job 38:15.2)

note.note: BHS has been faithful to the Leningrad Codex where there might be a question of the validity of the form and we keep the same form as BHS.
We have added a sop pasuq where L and BHS omit it. (The added sof pasuq often is missing from the text.)
We read or understand L differently than BHS. Often this notation indicates a typographical error in BHS.
Puncta extraordinaria -- a \u05c4 is used to mark such marks in the text when they are above the line and a \u05c5 when they are below the line.
Large letter(s). Shown as large letters without a superscript note number.
Small letter(s). Shown as small letters without a superscript note number.
Suspended letter(s). Shown as suspended letters without a superscript note number.
Inverted nun in the text.
BHS has abandoned L and we concur. All of these occurrences are ketib/qere problems.
Adaptations to a Qere which L and BHS, by their design, do not indicate.
We read one or more accents in L differently than BHS. Often this notation indicates a typographical error in BHS.
We read one or more consonants in L differently from BHS.
Miscellaneous notes to the text and occasions where more than one bracket category applies.
Marks an anomalous form.
We read punctuation in L differently from BHS.
We have abandoned or added a ketib/qere relative to BHS. In doing this we agree with L against BHS.
We read one or more vowels in L differently from BHS.
Yathir readings in L which we have designated as Qeres when both Dothan and BHS list a Qere.
We read one or more accents in L differently from BHQ.
Marks a consonant with an anomalous final form that is word-medial.
We read one or more consonants in L differently from BHQ. (Currently unused.)
Marks a word with a final consonant that is a medial (not a final) form.
